The Sarabhaṅga Jātaka
“Adorned with earrings, well-dressed,
with crystal, pearl, and gold ornaments,
standing in the chariot, who are you?
How do they know you in the world of humans?”
“I am Aṭṭhaka, and this is Bhīmaratha,
and this is the king of Kāliṅga, Uggatoya.
We have come to see the well-concentrated seers
and have been asked these questions.”
“You stand in the sky, in the firmament,
like the moon on the fifteenth day.
I ask you, Yakkha of great power,
how do they know you in the world of humans?”
“They call you Sujā’s husband among the gods,

analyzed: maghavā ati tam āhu manussa loke
translated: and Maghavā in the world of humans.
That king of gods has now arrived here
to see the well-concentrated seers.”
“We have heard of the seers who have come from afar,
endowed with great power and spiritual abilities.
With a serene mind, I pay homage to you, Ayaris,

analyzed: ye jīva loka ittha manussa seṭṭhā
translated: who are the best among humans in this world of living beings.”
“The scent of seers who have long been pointed out,
Comes from their bodies, and goes with the wind.
Turning away from here, O thousand-eyed one,
The scent of seers is impure, O King of the Gods.”
“The scent of seers who have long been pointed out,
Comes from their bodies, and goes with the wind.
Like a garland of various fragrant flowers,
We expect this scent, reverend Sir;

analyzed: na ha ittha devā paṭikkūla saññinaḥ

“The giver of wealth, the lord of beings, the famous one,

analyzed: devānam indo sakkaḥ maghavā su jampati

Desires an opportunity to ask a question.
Who of these wise men here,

And of the three kings, the lords of men,
And of the lord of the gods, Vāsava?”
“This seer Sarabhanga, the ascetic,
Since birth has abstained from sexual intercourse;
The son of Ācara, well-disciplined,
He will answer these questions.”
“Koṇḍañña, answer the questions,
The sages, who are good in appearance, ask you.
This is the Dhamma among human beings,

What a patient, good person attains,

“One who is restrained in body and speech,

“Wisdom is the best of all things, the wise declare,
As the moon is the best of all stars;
Morality, glory, and truth,
Follow the wise man as his shadow.
“I approve of your well-spoken words;

original: Aññaṁ taṁ pucchāmi tadiṅgha brūhi;🔽Kathaṅkaro kintikaro kimācaraṁ,

“One should serve the wise and the learned,
Be eager to learn and ask questions;
One should listen with attention to good sayings;
Thus one becomes wise and lives long.
“The wise man considers the strands of sensual pleasure
As impermanent, as suffering, as a disease;
Thus he overcomes desire,
For sensual pleasures are full of suffering and great dangers.
“Free from desire, he should overcome hatred,
And develop the immeasurable mind of loving-kindness;
Laying aside the rod against all beings,
The blameless one goes to the realm of Brahma.”
“Your coming has been of great profit,
To you, to Mattaka, and to Bhimaratha;
And to the king of Kalinga, who has risen up,
All of you have abandoned sensual lust.”
“So it is, one who knows the minds of others,
All our sensual lust has been abandoned;
Make an opportunity for us to serve,
So that we may attain to your state.”
“I make an opportunity for you to serve,

analyzed: tathā hi vaḥ kāma rāgaḥ pahīnaḥ

Be always devoted to meditation, concentrated,

original: Yo kocimā aṭṭhikatvā suṇeyya,🔽Labhetha pubbāpariyaṁ visesaṁ;

translated: Whoever listens to them attentively,🔽will attain distinction in this life;

Sāriputta is the rice-field,
Kassapa is the bull,
Anuruddha is the mountain,
Kaccāyana and Devala,
Ānanda is the disciple,
Kisāgotamī and Khemā,
Nārada and the elder Udāyī,
the assembly is the Buddha's assembly;
Sarabhaṅga is the Lord of the World,
thus should the jātaka be remembered.
The Sarabhaṅga Jātaka is the second.
